awd_titl_txt: Investigating the Emission of Sounds by the Mammalian Ear Using a Computational Model
awd_abstract_narration:
The function of the mammalian inner ear is to detect sounds. However, the inner ear is not just a sensory system; it can also emit sounds that can be measured by placing a microphone in the ear canal. These sounds, called otoacoustic emissions, are commonly used to obtain indirect information about inner ear function. Because of the noninvasive and low-cost nature of otoacoustic emission measurements, otoacoustic emissions have not only scientific applications but also clinical applications such as newborn hearing screening tests. Unfortunately, many aspects of otoacoustic emissions are still poorly understood, which limits how much information can be obtained from these measurements. This project aims to develop a clear understanding of mammalian otoacoustic emissions. The results from this fundamental research will help to improve hearing screening tests, auditory prostheses and cochlear implants. Hence this project could have a tremendous societal impact since about 50 million Americans suffer from some level of hearing loss. Additionally, the knowledge gained from this research about hearing biomechanics will help to design novel sensors that mimic the function of the inner ear. This award will support the interdisciplinary training of graduate students in biomechanics, biophysics, acoustics and computational modeling. This research will involve participation of women and students from underrepresented groups and will be disseminated to a broader audience.

This research will focus on a specific type of otoacoustic emissions, called distortion product otoacoustic emissions. Distortion product otoacoustic emissions are emitted in response to a two-tone stimulus due to the nonlinearity of the inner ear. Current experiments and models are unable to conclusively establish the precise site of generation of distortion product otoacoustic emissions. Furthermore, several hypotheses exist regarding the primary path for the propagation of distortion product otoacoustic emission from their site of generation to the ear canal. To address these questions, this research will use physiologically-based computational models of the mammalian ear that include key features not included in other models of otoacoustic emissions. These models couple a lumped parameter model of the middle ear to three-dimensional finite element models of the inner ear.  Numerical simulations will be used to determine where otoacoustic emissions are generated and how they propagate from their site of generation to the ear canal. These theoretical results will be validated and tested by comparison to experimental data provided by collaborators.

por.por_cntn:
Normal hearing requires amplification of low amplitude sound-evoked vibrations by outer hair cells in the inner ear. Due to the nonlinearity of outer hair cells, sound emitted by the inner ear, called distortion product otoacoustic emissions, can be measured in the ear canal in response to a two-tone stimulus. Because distortion product otoacoustic emissions are generated by outer hair cells, they are commonly measured to provide noninvasive information about outer hair cell function in clinical and research applications. This project aimed to address two previously resolved questions regarding otoacoustic emission generation: (1) where exactly these emissions are generated within the inner ear and (2) how these emissions propagate from their generation location within the inner ear to the middle ear

To achieve these objectives, a physiologically-motivated computational model of the ear of a mammalian species commonly used in hearing research, the gerbil, was developed. After calibration of the model using in vivo data, model predictions for the three-dimensional spatial variations of the intracochlear fluid pressure were analyzed and compared to available in vivo experimental data to determine how distortion product otoacoustic emissions propagate within the cochlea. Results show that distortion product otoacoustic emissions propagate as slow propagating waves on the basilar membrane. To evaluate where these emissions are generated within the model, three different methods were used: (1) the electrical output of the outer hair cells was analyzed; (2) local damage was applied to outer hair cells to eliminate local generation of distortion products; (3) an interference tone was added to cause nonlinear suppression of the distortion product response. Analysis of the simulation results indicates that distortion products are primarily generated due to nonlinear distortion at cochlear locations where the response of the two primary tones have a high magnitude. These findings regarding the generation and propagation of distortion product otoacoustic emissions advance fundamental knowledge regarding the biophysics and biomechanics of the inner ear and the generation of otoacoustic emissions. The detailed predictions of the intracochlear response to a two-tone stimulus provide insight into cochlear biophysics beyond what an experimental approach can provide.

Hearing loss is a major societal problem that affects millions of Americans. Because otoacoustic emissions are commonly used to diagnose hearing loss, the results of this project will have broader impacts on the clinical application of these emissions as noninvasive diagnosis tools. Improved fundamental knowledge of cochlear mechanics will also help improved auditory prostheses and cochlear implants for restoring hearing. This project provided partial support for the multidisciplinary training of three graduate students in biomechanics, biophysics, computational modeling, acoustics and vibrations. The principal investigator developed modules about hearing mechanics for his undergraduate and graduate classes in acoustics. A website was created to disseminate the results of this research to a broader audience.
